content: We're currently looking for the opinion of any other ordinal user, that generalizing succ to order.succ but losing dot notation is a worthwhile change.

I strongly believe it to be so, since otherwise we'd need to either prove various duplicate lemmas on ordinal.succ (which was the case before this PR), or constantly rewrite ordinal.succ to order.succ and viceversa
@Mario Carneiro @Floris van Doorn What do you think?
I might as well mention I'm doing a similar refactor on cardinalat #14273, in case anyone wants to comment on that
Yes, I think it would be very good to use order.succ for ordinal.succ and cardinal.succ.
Losing dot notation is not a reason to avoid the general class.

I'm not an ordinal user (but will be in a few weeks!), but I should point out that people should really get into the habit of opening the order namespace (I know you couldn't precisely because ordinal.succ and cardinal.succ are a thing, Violeta). In that case, (succ o) won't even be much longer than o.succ.
I would argue that open order is maybe a bad idea, and that open order (succ) is probably a bit safer
